stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream re-engineering the Goomba King boss fight: fixing spikey Goomba bugs, coding new AI so Goombas push a boulder into the king, tweaking collision, and planning missing animations and door assets. He also shows recent engine fixes (mip-maps, N64 lights, crash removal) and experiments with an N64 bloom shader. Marketing talk about upcoming YouTube videos and titles surfaces repeatedly.

development_findings.summary: Main task was a full rework of the Goomba King boss per Biobak’s request: spikey Goombas, boulder-pushing logic, new AI states, and geometry tweaks were coded and mostly completed except for two animations and boss doors.
development_findings.quote: "Your mission today is fixing the Goombas fight. … You have to aim the boulder at him."

development_findings.summary: Implemented texture mipmaps and repaired N64 light maps after discovering a macro mistake, eliminating shimmer and restoring hardware lighting.
development_findings.quote: "Look at this. Mipmaps. I did it… I also fixed the lights on N64."

development_findings.summary: Fixed several N64-specific crashes in the area and verified the level now approaches 60 FPS after collision optimisations that merged redundant triangles.
Attempted an N64 bloom effect borrowed from another dev; it works visually but costs ~7 ms of RDP time, so may be reserved for small sub-areas.
development_findings.quote: "It is brighter, you have to admit that… it cost him 7 milliseconds of RDP time."

development_findings.summary: Refactored random position code for Goomba AI (switching 0–1 range to –1–1) and corrected radius/diameter confusion to stabilise movement.
Decided any future UI overhaul must feel like a natural evolution of Mario 64’s HUD, not a wholesale transplant from later games.
Identified missing animations: kick, angry/jump, proper idle-walk sync; Zeina will create these along with an updated shadow fade.
development_findings.quote: "I’m going to write Zeina the animations we need."

context_findings.summary: Kaze purposely attracts negative comments to harvest feedback and says he is largely unaffected emotionally.
context_findings.quote: "I’m the kind of person who will purposefully attract negative comments just to get feedback."

context_findings.summary: He stresses that the channel’s long-term goal is an original N64-style game, not endless vanilla optimisation; plans explanatory video soon.
Believes game-dev success requires borderline obsessive persistence: "you need to be completely insane" and create self-imposed punishments to finish tasks.
context_findings.quote: "If you want to be successful making video games you need to be mentally unwell."

context_findings.summary: Expresses concern over recent Nintendo takedowns; legal action is costly, so he currently relies on caution rather than lawyers.
He is experimenting with click-driven YouTube titles but worries about falling into “YouTube slop” content buckets.
Admits streaming more often leaves him exhausted, hinting at work-life balance limits.

biobak.summary: Requested specific changes to Goomba King fight and provided new Goomba King model plus boss-door assets.
Suggested higher-impact video titles, e.g., "The secret reason I’ve been rewriting Mario 64," which Kaze believes could triple views.

zeina.summary: Responsible for Goomba King’s animations; current model shows issues (one leg up, missing kick/angry loops) and will deliver new sets.

key_stories.title: Reworking the Goomba King Boss
key_stories.summary: The original Goomba King encounter felt weak, so Biobak proposed a full redesign. Kaze spent the stream coding new AI where Goombas push a boulder toward the king, fixing animation bugs, and refining collision. Only two animations and door triggers remain.
key_stories.challenge: Modernise an early-game boss so it’s fun and technically solid on real N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Debug disappearing spikey Goombas, rewrite movement maths, adjust push mechanics, and clean up level geometry.
key_stories.outcome: Core logic works; finishing touches (kick/angry animations, door reveal) are delegated to Zeina and Biobak.
key_stories.key_quote: "All that’s missing now is the two animations and the boss doors."

key_stories.title: Chasing N64 Bloom
key_stories.summary: Kaze attempted to add a post-process bloom effect to retain modern lighting flair on original hardware. The shader works but consumes 7 ms of RDP time, threatening performance.
key_stories.challenge: Introduce bloom without tanking frame-rate on the N64.
key_stories.process: Imported another dev’s shader, tested visually in-game, and measured timing.
key_stories.outcome: Effect shelved for selective use in small, controlled sub-areas.
key_stories.key_quote: "If it’s only 7 ms, it is usable in sub-areas that are really close to perfect."
